qas.question: Who has noted that binding precedent did not exist when the Constitution was written?
Why were decisions not reported or recoded correctly?

answers.text: reporters often simply rewrote or failed to publish decisions which they disliked

qas.question: What are the natural theories of law that that the English judges in the eighteenth century used?

answers.text: law was believed to have an existence independent of what individual judges said

qas.question: Why could one judge reject another judges opinion?

answers.text: saw themselves as merely declaring the law which had always theoretically existed, and not as making the law

qas.question: Why would one judge reject another's opinion?
What began at the time the Constitution was framed?
What was the name of the judge who believed he was declaring a pre-existing law?
When did the natural law theory fall out of fashion?
Reporters were not allowed to prevent publication based on what?
What did the the UK courts in the end of the 19th century?

context: As <a0_0>federal judge <b6_0>Alex Kozinski<b6_0/><a0_0/> has pointed out, <b5_0>binding precedent<b5_0/> as we know it today simply did not exist at the time the Constitution was framed. Judicial decisions were not consistently, accurately, and faithfully reported on both sides of the Atlantic (<a1_0>reporters often simply rewrote or failed to publish decisions <b8_0>which they disliked<b8_0/><a1_0/>), and the United Kingdom lacked a <b9_0>coherent court hierarchy<b9_0/> prior to the end of the 19th century. Furthermore, English judges in <b7_0>the eighteenth century<b7_0/> subscribed to now-obsolete natural law theories of law, by which <a2_0>law was believed to have an existence independent of what individual judges said<a2_0/>. Judges <a3_0>saw themselves as merely declaring the law which had always theoretically existed, and not as making the law<a3_0/>. Therefore, a judge could reject another judge's opinion as simply an <a4_0>incorrect statement of the law<a4_0/>, in the way that scientists regularly reject each other's conclusions as incorrect statements of the laws of science.
